Take a good care of your health reader | 03.24.04 - 4:37 pm | # Thank you reader for the advice, yup, I do agree that health comes on top of all. But I'd be lying to myself if I say that my weight doesn't worry me, both health and appearance wise. I'm not saying that I should be skinny, but I do think that I will feel better about myself if I lose a few pounds â the right way! I have lost weight quite dramatically a few years back. Yes, I felt so much better, how could I not? My athma attacks became less frequent, PLUS, I could fit into normal clothing! No more trips to the plus size department, or even worse, men's! But back then, I don't think the way I shed the pounds was entirely on the right track. I exercised, that was good, but I'd also skipped my meal, which was bad news...that was y I wasn't so proud n comfortable when people kept asking me tips on losing weight - the only drawback of me being slim though... And so I thought... but I was wrong... only to realized that the damage has been doneâ¦ today, Iâve been diagnosed with PCOSâ¦ short for Poly Cystic Ovary Syndrome, I think â¦ Iâve suspected this for quite a while now, well since reading a gossip magazine this one dayâ¦ I read about Posh and Kym Marsh who both had this syndrome and described what the symptoms were, two of them being âmissing or irregular period and weight gainâ- the worrying duos that Iâve had since foreverâ¦ see, there is sum good in reading tabloids! As most of the symptoms fit me well (not only period n weight), I began doing research on PCOSâ¦I also bought Mrs Beckhamâs autobiography for crying out loud! I have seen doctors in Malaysia about this period problem before, around 98/99 I thinkâ¦ but their reply was â adik tak sexually active lagi, so, nothing to worry about! Biase je niâ¦â Well, Posh has been diagnosed since she was 13 or 15 â sometime around that, and I doubt that she was sexually active then! So, I went to see my GP, who kindly sets me up with this Gynae, and the rest is historyâ¦ The thing about PCOS is, losing weight is SO SO HARD (as Huda has mentioned in one of her informative comments). Gaining weight on the other hand, will be like âalmost alwaysâ, as what is happening to me right nowâ¦ Skipping meals like what I did before even made it worse, as I need the right balance of food especially to treat PCOS. Carbs are bad for us, but at the same time are very important to balance the hormones that would help develop the menstrual cycle properlyâ¦ these contrasting facts made it more difficult to tailor the rite diet for usâ¦ But Iâm on medication rite now, as prescribed by my Gynaeâ¦ she said, if I lose weight, it would help a great dealâ¦ she asks me to exercise and eat riteâ¦ So, to all my kind readers, my earlier entry was not meant to tell all the fat girls out there to go lose their weight just for the sake of appearancesâ¦ appearance is just the bonus of it all, weâll feel more confident then everâ¦ but donât ever risk our health for it! What we want is both to look good and HEALTHY! Oh, by the way, having this PCOS also means that my chances of getting pregnant are rather slimâ¦ I told my gynae that I want to start trying after my studies and sheâll help with the right medication laterâ¦ so, pray for me k? I would also like to thank Juri for âtemaningâ me to my ultrasound scan appointment todayâ¦ he missed a very important match today because of this, and I can see that heâs rather upset because the team mates kept asking him y he didnât turn upâ¦ I went to the football pitch earlier and I can see how important he was among the footballers thereâ¦ so honey, thank you sooo much for missing it for me! I do believe that my childhood played an enormous part in shaping my personality, apart from my adolescence world which was full of confusion. I was both a happy and unhappy child. But now, all I can think of are the unhappy memoriesâ¦People may be asking of how unhappy a child like me can be? I am not adopted nor physically abused, my family seems to be reasonably fine and I was a brilliant kid back then. But hey, you have no ideaâ¦ Every now and then, people kept saying that being fat is not a big deal, as long as youâre happy, physical appearance wonât mean anything. I beg to differ. Basing on my experience, and by this, I mean my whole life, I am never happy when it comes to my appearance. Each time I tried to be fine with it, thinking that people are civilised enough not to make fun of me nor would they discourage me from accepting my fat self â I was proved wrong, every single time. How can I think that itâs fine when my own school teacher publicly asked me âeh, awak ni takde baju lain yg tak ketat ke?â leaving me embarrassed but still smiling (I was trying my best to keep my cool n just be polite), that was darjah empat, when I had to wear my Cik Suâs blue kurung as I was appointed prefect and needed a new uniform there and then. When I was in standard 6, a friend of my mumâs asked me the exact same question in front of my normal slim friends and siblings. I sadly laughed along with them to cover the humiliation. Then, there was this two aunties gossiping about pairing anak die ni ngan anak die tu, when it came to me being paired with her son, the response was âeh tak nak la, besar sgtââ¦ not that I give a tiny rat ass about her son, but please, I was deeply hurt. Adults are just so MEAN. I always tried to be normal, tried to have the sense of belonging, especially to my family, relatives and close friends. But it was too hard. When ever there was something new in fashion and every kid was wearing the same thing, I was being left out. When other kids were joyously climbing on ladders and walls, I couldnât help but think of the humiliation I had to bear should the ladder brokeâ¦ I was also mistaken as my dadâs sister since I looked too old for my age. Okay, so I can go on forever with the weight issue. But my point here is, I donât think that people are really sincere when they say that itâs OK being fat. Iâm sorry if you really believe in it, but my childhood experiences proved quite the opposite.
